Sustainable Gardening

Composting
Companion Planting
Carbon Sequestration

What does it mean to practice sustainability

In an environment of climate change and extensive environmental damage, the minimal effort exercised when practicing sustainability is a sensible approach to complement the pursuit of urban agriculture. Sharing this view are numerous gardeners across Australia who have come to realize that creating a sustainable garden is not only beneficial for you and your plants, but significantly contributes to improvements in the environment around you.

No Sight of Chemicals

Commitment to 100% Organic Inputs

Re - use of Resources

Zero Waste Through Composting

Diverse Ecosystem

Balance Through Companion Planting

Promote Healthy Soil

Soil Treatment Through Carbon Sequestration

Composting

Supplementing the growth of your garden is a well maintained compost. Beyond fueling growth, composting can also restore the quality and vitality of depleted soil. And the best part is, composting is inexpensive, environmental friendly and easy to pursue. 

Benefits

  • By introducing your garden to compost, you create a rich humus for your soil, which in turn adds nutrients and helps retain moisture. It introduces into the soil beneficial, microscopic organisms that help aerate the soil, break down organic material for plant use and ward off disease — hence, Black Gold. 
  • Composting encourages recycling and the redirection of waste away from the landfill and into the ground (organic waste landfills does not break down properly, resulting in the creation of methane that ultimately, when released into the air, contributes to global warming and climate change)
Tips

ACTIVATORS 

To speed up composting, include ‘activators’ such as comfrey leaves, young weeds and grass clippings. Mixing finished compost with fresh compost can help quicken the process as well. 

ODORS 

Suburban spaces do make the odors emitted from composting a challenge to overcome, but it is important to avoid meat and bone scraps in your compost, this can result in unpleasant odors resulting from the breakdown process. 

Adding lime or calcium can further help if the compost emits foul odor. 

PESTS 

As composting includes food wastes, it has the potential to attract pests and fruit flies. To keep them at bay, add dry leaves and grass clippings to the compost to mask the smell and limit the exposure to food waste. 

Build your own

DIY BINS 

A cost-efficient technique using a garbage can, all you have to do is 

  • Drill aeration holes in rows at roughly 15 cm intervals around the can. 
  • Fill the can with a mix of carbon and nitrogen rich materials
  • Stir the contents to avoid anaerobic pockets (as well as to speed up the composting process)

DIGESTERS 

Otherwise known as ‘Compost Bins’, they are enclosed on all sides except the bottom, so they are directly against the ground. Ideal for areas where bins need to be smaller, but can be challenging to turn and hence, take a longer while to generate a healthy compost. Also, depending on the wall linings of the bin, some material might not withstand harsh external pressures (strong winds, excessive moisture and so on.)

TUMBLERS 

Compost tumblers are fairly efficient enclosed bins due to their capacity to provide insulation along with the rotatory motion that keeps microbes aerated and active. 

Some systems further enhance aeration provided by the compost tumbler, making for a speedier composting process, and the high internal temperature can allow for year-long composting. 

This keeps compost neatly enclosed and odor free, ideal for residential units. 

Companion Planting

Benefits

  • Companion Planting can act as a form of integrated pest management. This eliminates the need for artificial, chemical pest control measures. 
  • Companion planting, when done right, can mimic the biodiversity prevalent in nature. The key is to avoid monoculture, which in turn reduces the likelihood of attracting pests that feed on specific families. This also attracts favorable insects that can further improve the state of your garden. 
  • Growing combinations of edibles alongside each other has been proven to enhance the flavor of outputs generated. 
    Tips

    IDEAL COMBINATIONS 

    A favorable approach to companion planting would include a balance of plants that 

    • attract pollinators 
    • repel pests and diseases 
    • improve the flavor of accompanying edibles.  
    • improve the nutrient content of the soil
    • provide shelter  (such as tall vines alongside plants in need of shade)

    To provide further assistance on companion planting, check out The Department of Primary Industry and Resources’ factsheet on plants that complement each other (along with combinations to avoid!)

    Explore Factsheet

    Carbon Sequestration

    Carbon sequestration is a process wherein carbon from the atmosphere is captured by the ground and in turn, used in the lifecycle of the plant. 

    Background

    • To understand how to trap carbon into the soil, a reminder into how the carbon cycle interacts with plants :

      Chlorophyll (the green color in plants) in the presence of sunlight and water helps plants convert carbon dioxide into sugars in the process of photosynthesis. 

      These sugars then contribute to the development and growth of the plant. 

      The carbon from the air is stored in plants tissues, where it stays until the plant decays into the soil, in which case carbon finds its way right back into the ground where it continues to benefit the soil and its capacity to produce healthy plants. 

      Implementing Carbon Farming involves key strategies : 

      Effective decision making in planting choices and the combination of plants maintained in the garden 

      Capturing organic material through informed soil maintenance and the avoidance of practices that in turn deplete the soil carbon content. 

      Benefits

      Captures Carbon in the air and traps it into the soil, which is used in the plants lifecycle. 

      Carbon emissions and carbon content in the atmosphere has seen an unhealthy rise over the years through human activity, and is especially prevalent in urban areas due to population density and the excessive emissions of carbon through urban activity and lifestyle practices. 

      Soil is seen as one of the most promising sinks that can guide the offset of carbon emissions in the atmosphere if conducted consciously. 

      Due to the space constraint associated with gardening in urban areas, it is crucial to ensure that the resources employed (soil, manure, seeds and fertilizers) are utilized to the best of their capacity to produce a favorable output. Effectively employing carbon sequestration can improve the quality of the soil, making for an enhanced platform to grow on.

      Tips

      Healthy soil, or a healthy compost pile, should ideally contain more carbon than nitrogen. But finding the right balance is key in providing for your garden. Carbon rich material gives soil and compost a light body which allows oxygen to penetrate and nourish the organisms that reside there, whereas nitrogen include protein rich matter that provide the raw materials needed to make enzymes. 

      An ideal ratio would be one-third nitrogen to two-third carbon. Suggestions include : 

      Carbon (Brown)

      • Wood chips, wood ash
      • straw/hay
      • Shredded paper, newspapers
      • Cardboard 
      • Leaves
      Nitrogen (Green)

      • Tea Leaves 
      • Table Scraps 
      • Grass Clippings 
      • Fruit and Vegetable Scraps 
      • Coffee Grounds
